entry.title: CURP Validation in SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central Using Business Rules
entry.content:
Introduction: Enhancing Standard Format Checks with Logic-Based Validation

When working with SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central, ensuring the accuracy of national identifiers is critical ‚Äî especially for country-specific IDs like the Mexican CURP (Clave √önica de Registro de Poblaci√≥n).

As you may know, Employee Central does offer a standard CURP validation, but it's restricted to format checking. It ensures the CURP is 18 characters and follows the right structure ‚Äî but it does not validate the embedded logic, like date of birth, gender, or state code.

If you‚Äôve struggled with CURP validation in SuccessFactors, or you're looking to make your system more robust and compliant, this solution is simple and scalable.

In this blog, I‚Äôll share how I implemented a custom Business Rule to take CURP validation a step further ‚Äî by checking that the value entered is not just syntactically correct, but also logically valid based on employee data.

Standard vs. Enhanced Validation

Validation Type       

 Format Check (Standard)

 Logic Check (Custom Rule)

 Length (18 chars)     

 ‚úÖ Yes                  

 ‚úÖ Yes                    

 Character pattern     

 ‚úÖ Yes                  

 ‚úÖ Yes                    

 Date of birth matching

 ‚ùå No                   

 ‚úÖ Yes                    

 Gender validation     

 ‚ùå No                   

 ‚úÖ Yes                    

 State code validation 

 ‚ùå No                   

 ‚úÖ Yes                    

As shown above, the standard validation stops at format. With the Business Rule we extend that to cross-check the CURP content against the employee‚Äôs own data ‚Äî a must-have for maintaining high-quality HR records.

Where This Rule Lives

The rule is configured in the National ID portlet of Employee Central and applies specifically when ID Type = CURP. It triggers during the Hire/Rehire onSave event to ensure validation before saving the record.

I‚Äôll be sharing the exact configuration, regex pattern, and logical checks I used ‚Äî including how we:

  • Parse CURP values to extract DOB, gender, and state code
  • Compare them with the employee‚Äôs actual personal data
  • Raise friendly error messages when something doesn‚Äôt match

Why Bother with Logic Checks?

Here‚Äôs why this matters:

  • Compliance: Inaccurate CURPs can lead to issues with government filings and audits.
  • Data Integrity: Avoid storing incorrect identifiers that may affect integrations or reporting.
  • User Experience: Prevent users from unknowingly entering wrong data that gets saved without warning.

Stay Tuned

In my next section below, I‚Äôll walk you through:

  • The full business rule logic I used
  • The regex pattern for CURP format validation
  • How to match CURP-encoded DOB with the employee‚Äôs `dateOfBirth` field
  • State code validation using `Picklist` or constant arrays

This is a no-code, configuration-only solution that doesn‚Äôt require any external tools ‚Äî just SAP standard functionality and a smart business rule.

Proposed Solution

Business Rule Variants

The logic in CURP involves checking consonants and vowels based on specific characters. To perform this validation, we need to create variants to find these values. Unfortunately, we have to create three different variants for all consonants, since the validations are performed in three different fields. The variants should be created as shown in the example below:

Business Rule Conditions

Moving on to the conditions that we must have the rule to perform all validations, below I will break down the explanation according to each part of the CURP logic, this way it will be easier to understand.

You'll notice that in the rule conditions below, I'm already considering "transforming" the name field letters into uppercase, since in ID they are always capitalized. This prevents the name fields from being all filled in with capital letters. If the customer requests the name fields in uppercase, I recommend removing this function from the rule.

 

  1. In the first condition, it is checked whether it is not CURP, the rule is already skipped, in this way we optimize and contribute to the performance of the System.

For this validation I have added the two letters of each state of birth to the picklist label, to make it simple, and in the rule, we are reading that value inside of the parentheses. Example below of a picklist value.

Sample from Demo

Note: If you have defined the ‚ÄúState of Birth‚Äù as part of the Biographical Information CSF it will not be possible to retrieve this data, as the rule has a limitation today and does not allow us to access this table.

Sample from Demo

Additional Resources

As the rule has many validations and extensive variants, I am sharing the rule in a format to be imported but remember that the configuration you have may be a little different from my demo, so after importing you will have to make possible adjustments. Download HERE.

I'm also sharing HERE the link to the guide that explains all the rule functions in case you want to delve deeper into the ones used in the rule.

Conclusion

While SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central provides a good foundation for CURP validation through standard format checks, it's not enough to guarantee data accuracy and compliance in real-world scenarios. By implementing a custom Business Rule, we can go beyond the basics and ensure that CURP values not only follow the expected structure but also make logical sense based on the employee‚Äôs personal information.

This approach is entirely configuration-based, requires no custom development, and is easy to maintain ‚Äî making it a smart enhancement for any organization operating in Mexico.

Validating CURP logic at the point of entry helps avoid downstream errors, ensures alignment with legal requirements, and maintains the integrity of your HR data.

I hope this solution helps you improve your Employee Central setup. Feel free to reach out or comment if you‚Äôd like to share how you‚Äôve tackled CURP validation in your own environment.

entry.title: From Cloud Foundry to Cloud Run : The Journey of Integrating SAP BTP with Google Cloud Platform
entry.content:
Bridging the Clouds Series. Part 1

When I set out to integrate an SAP Fiori App deployed on SAP BTP Cloud Foundry with a backend service on google cloud run, the goal was to securely connect the two platforms without relying on long-lived service account keys. The backend cloud run services- powered by Vertex AI , hosted our trained AI Models and prediction endpoints - making GCP the natural choice for its advanced AI capabilities. I've always believed in practical solutions over overly engineered ones, so my focus was on building a secure, scalable and maintainable integration that just works.

To achieve this, I configured XSUAA for authentication in the Fiori app, set up a destination in SAP BTP to connect to SAP API Hub, and used the API Hub as a secure API Gateway to validate and forward requests. On the GCP side, I enabled Workload Identity Federation, allowing SAP to authenticate with GCP services without exposing credentials. This blog shares my journey, the architecture and the lessons learned while bridging SAP BTP and GCP using modern identity federation techniques.

The Architecture: Bridging Two Worlds

The first step was to visualize how the pieces would fit together. On one side, I had the SAP Fiori app running on Cloud Foundry in SAP BTP, authenticating via XSUAA. On the other hand, a Google Cloud Run service exposing AI Powered endpoints. SAP API Hub Proxy is created for the connecting between the Fiori app and the GCP cloud Run services. The proxy abstracts the connection  setup between Fiori app and the cloud run service.

Process Flow Diagram

 

The Flow diagram illustrates the flow:

  1. SAP Fiori App ‚Üí Authenticated via XSUAA
  2. Destination in BTP ‚Üí Points to SAP API Hub
  3. SAP API Hub ‚Üí Forwards requests to GCP
  4. Google Cloud Run ‚Üí Hosts the Backend Service (AI -enabled)
  5. Workload Identity Federation ‚Üí Authenticates SAP with GCP using OIDC

Using this setup you can either hard-code the service account keys in SAP API Hub key value mapping or setup connectivity using identity federation.

(Ironically, my "Practical" solution at first was to use service account key and mark  it as a working model.üòä )

The Implementation : Step by Step

1. Setting up Fiori App & XSUAA Component üõ†Ô∏è

Well, I began building  the Fiori app, I knew it didn't need to be flashy -- just functional. The goal was to create a lightweight UI that could securely communicate with our backend AI services on Google cloud run.. SO, I fired up SAP Business Application Studio (BAS) , my go-to IDE for SAP Development and got to work.

Fiori App Development

The app was a freestyle app with a list report and a details page with a pdf file viewer control -- no fancy charts or animations - just clean and simple. Once the UI was in place, I moved on to the real backbone of the app : authentication and routing.

Configuring XSUAA and Routing

To secure the app, I created an xs-security.json file where I defined the roles and scopes. This will allow to control access at a granular level and ensure only authorized users could trigger backend calls (not just backend calls, even static page calls as wellü§ù) .

 

 

 

‚ÄúDefining roles and scopes in xs-security.json‚Äù

Next, I configured the xs-app.json to define the routes. This setup mapped frontend requests to the backend destination configured in SAP BTP. Nothing new in xs-app.json, authenticationtype set to xsuaa to enable xsuaa service to handle the authentication for my app. The destination property in the xs-app is set as the destination created in SAP BTP for my SAP API Hub Proxy.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

SAP API Proxy Destination in SAP BTP

Once the routing was defined, the next step was to set up a destination in SAP BTP that could act as a connector to the SAP API Hub proxy,  which in turn securely forward requests to the google cloud run services. I created a destination in SAP BTP pointing it to the SAP API Hub Proxy Url. The destination was configured as shown below :

 

This destination was then referenced in the xs-app.json route, allowing the Fiori app to securely communicate with the backend service without exposing any credentials.

Deployment to Cloud Foundry

With everything wired up, I deployed the app to SAP BTP Cloud Foundry. Once deployed, the app was visible under HTML5 repository and was able to see the xsuaa service for the deployed app.

 

The destination, htlm5 and xsuaa services were updated as well in instance section.

 

XSUAA:  Backbone of Authentication

If there is one component that truly held this integration together, it is XSUAA. while the app itself was lightweight and the backend powerful, the real connectivity happened in the API Proxy - where identity and trust were established.

In my setup , Azure AD(now Entra ID) was the corporate identity provider. But instead of integrating it directly with the Fiori app, I configured XSUAA as the intermediary. This allowed me to leverage SAP BTP's native security model while still authenticating users against Entra ID.

Once the JWT is issued by XSUAA ‚Äî after validating and re-signing the token received from Entra ID ‚Äî it becomes the key to accessing backend services. The  GCP backend service uses the public key exposed by XSUAA to validate the token‚Äôs signature, ensuring its authenticity. Once validated, the token is decoded and its claims are inspected ‚Äî particularly the scopes and roles ‚Äî to determine whether the user is authorized to access the requested data.

 

Issues Faced During Implementation

No integration story is complete without a few bumps along the way. 

1. Role Collection Confusion

Even though I had defined roles in xs-security.json, users were getting unauthorized errors. Turns out, I had forgotten to assign the role collection to my user in the BTP cockpit. 

2. Token Forwarding

Initially, the token from XSUAA wasn't being forwarded properly to the backend. I had to explicitly enable token forwarding in the route configuration and ensure in the destination property forwardAuthToken was set as true.

2.Setting Up the SAP API Proxy

When it came to connecting SAP BTP to Google Cloud Run via the SAP API Hub, I explored two distinct paths - one familiar üòâ, one modern. Each had its own story, its own lessons.

Option 1: The ‚ÄúQuick and Dirty‚Äù Way ‚Äî Service Account Key File

Lets be honest - when you're racing against a deadline, the easiest path is often the one you've walked before. So my first attempt involved using a Google Cloud Service Account key file. I downloaded the JSON key, stored it securely (or so I thought), and configured the SAP API Hub to use it for authentication.

It worked Instantly!!!.

The key file was a "long-lived" credential - and by long lived, I mean a generous 3 months of quietly sitting around, waiting to be leaked. It is static, sensitive and just enough to keep me on edge every time I pushed code.

Still, it was a good starting point - a proof of concept that validated the integration.

How I implemented this Approach ? ü§î

Step 1 : Creating Key Value Maps in SAP API Hub

To avoid hardcoding sensitive values directly into the API Proxy, I used Key Value Maps (KVMs) - a secure way to store and retrieve configuration data within SAP API Hub.

I created 2 KVM's as shown below one encrypted and another one un-encrypted:

 

The encrypted key value map contains client_id and private_key value from the service account key json file. The un-encrypted key value map contains the URL of the google cloud run service and the service account that is used for authentication.

Below is a sample service account key json file :

 

Step 2 : Using KVM's in Proxy and triggering Cloud Run Service using Policies.

The first thing I needed was a gatekeeper - a policy that would check whether the incoming request from the fiori app included a valid authorization header. if the token was missing or malformed , the proxy would reject the request immediately.

No token? No entry. Simple as thatüõë .

Below is a sample SAP API Hub Policy Chart.

 

Looks Fancy right ?üòä. too many icons, policies, to be frank we don't need all. All it takes is just 4 to 5 policies.

Of course, if you're feeling adventurous - or just want to impress your future self - go ahead and include SAP's complete security template -- that's perfect for those who prefer their API's with a side of corporate elegance.

 

Lets see those 4 to 5 Policies needed:

  1. Extract Key value Pairs for un encrypted values 

 

2. Extract Key value Pairs for encrypted values 

  

By now, we have those key values in different variables that can be used across different policies using the request object.

Step 3: Generate a jwt using this service account key.

Using a dedicated generateJWT policy for a service account key a jwt can be created as shown below.

 

Step 4: Exchange jwt with google for access token

Once the jwt is created, exchange it with google for a google access token to trigger a cloud run service as below.

 

 

Hint : you can create a request body directly in this policy or can have another assign message policy to draft a request payload as shown below : 

 

Step 5: Use the access token to trigger GCP Services.

Add the access token as a bearer token in request header and call the google cloud run as shown below:

 

As you can see the request is just modified by adding a header property and this request is moved to backend (GCP).

The access token received in step 4 can be extracted from response using extractvariables policy as shown below:

 

Now, you may ask how the property that hold token values was identified and used in extractvariables policy. Here comes Postman .

Testing with Postman

Before wiring everything into the API Proxy, I needed to be sure I was extracting the right value from Google's token endpoint - specifically , the access token. I knew the response would be in JSON, but I wasn't sure what the exact structure looked like.

So, I did what any developer would do : I fired up Postman.

I manually crafted the JWT, set the headers and made a POST request to Google's OAuth 2.0 token endpoint. Within seconds , Postman returned a clean JSON response. And there it was - the golden key:

  

Option 2: The ‚ÄúRight‚Äù Way ‚Äî Workload Identity Federation

The right way of authentication using short lived tokens using workload identity federation.

How I implemented this Approach ?ü§î

It all began with a request from SAP BTP. Nestled inside was an authorization token , proudly bearing the "Bearer" prefix. But before this token could be of any use, it had to shed its formal attire. So, we stripped away the "Bearer" scheme, revealing the raw token underneath - ready for its next challenge. So, a javascript policy was crafted- small but mighty - to extract the raw token by stripping away the "Bearer" scheme as shown below.

 

Under scripts i created a javascript script to do the stripping!.

 

With this token in hand,i approached the google security token service (STS) - a token from a trusted identity provider. And Google , ever the caution gatekeeper, verified the token's origin and issued a shiny new federated token - one step closer to the goal.

lets see how the sts request payload looks like :

 

In the payload, we pass the audience the full path of the workload identity provider created in GCP for SAP BTP. best practice is to create individual provider for each IDP and if these IDP's are identical or similar they can grouped under a single Identity Pool. In subject_token we pass the stripped authorization token from BTP.

Next, lets see the actual request call : 

 

Now, lets extract the federated token from the response : 

 

How did I know the token is available in access_token property? Its the Postman.

 

But the journey wasn't over.

Next, we took this federated token to the IAM Credentials API, requesting an access token for a specific service account - one that had the permissions to invoke a cloud run service and for which mapping is done in workload identity federation. Google, satisfied with the federated token's lineage, handed over the access token .

Before we hit the IAM API, lets prepare the request payload.

 

The audience is your cloud run url . its can be any other services/ resources that supports workload identity federation.

Now, lets hit the IAM API for the token to call our cloud run service.

 

Now armed with this access token, we returned to the original request from BTP. We carefully inserted the token into the Authorization header Then we sent the request onward to Google Cloud.

Lets see how to extract the token from IAM API response and modify the original btp request with new token.

 

How did I know about the property "token"? Postman üòâ

 

Now, Modifying the BTP request:

 

And this time? No Rejections. No VPC walls. Just a smooth, secure handshake. Google Cloud verified the access token, recognized the service account, and welcomed the request with open arms.

Disclaimer: Choosing the Right IAM Credentials API Endpoint

When exchanging the federated token for an access token, Google provides 2 similar-looking endpoints:

  • generateAccessToken
  • generateIdToken

generateAccessToken is typically used when you're operating within Google Cloud and need to impersonate a service account to access GCP resources like Cloud Run, Cloud Storage, etc.

generateIdToken , on the other hand, is designed for authenticating external workloads .

Issues Faced & Lessons Learned : The Curious Case of the Missing IP

Just when everything seemed to be working smoothly - Postman tests were green, the SAP API Hub was running smooth and the federated token request was crafted with care - bam ! The call to Google Cloud's Security Token Service (STS) hit a wall. A very well-guarded, VPC - controlled wall.

The error? A cold, unwelcoming rejection from Google Cloud. The reason? The egress IP address of the SAP API Hub proxy wasn't whitelisted in the VPC service Controls. Classic! . Now, If you're working in a corporate network, this is the kind of delightful surprise you should absolutely expect. 

How did I got this details? Its my favourite Google VPC Logs üòé. See below for the log entry telling me that I violated a policy because my request was originated from this IP address.  So I whitelisted the cadr range in VPC Control firewall rules. 

 

Thankfully, SAP provides documentation that lists the egress IP address used by the SAP API Hub. Once we tracked it down and added the IP to the VPC allowlist, the token request sailed through like it was always meant to.

Reference : https://help.sap.com/docs/sap-api-management/sap-api-management-for-neo-environment/region-specific-ip-addresses-available-for-api-management-neo-environment?locale=en-US

Lesson Learned: When integrating across cloud platforms in enterprise environments, always account for network-level controls. 

The Final Piece of the Puzzle - Setting up Workload Identity Federation

Setting up workload Identity federation in Google Cloud is like preparing a backstage pass for your SAP BTP app to access GCP services - securely and with full control.

First, we created an identity pool and an identity provider in GCP, configuring it to trust tokens issued by SAP BTP's XSUAA. Then came the key part : attribute mapping. We mapped attribute.aud to assertion.aud, which corresponds to the name of the fiori app deployed in BTP - the same app for which XSUAA issued the JWT. This mapping is what allows google to recognize  and trust the incoming identity.

To allow the service account to be impersonated, we granted it the necessary roles and bound it to identities matching the mapped attributes. Now, the BTP token could be exchanged for a federated token, and then for an access token tied to the service account.

 

Important: The service account you intend to impersonate must have the roles/iam.workloadIdentityUser role granted on the identity pool. Without this, Google Cloud will not allow the federated identity to impersonate the service account, and the token exchange will fail.

But there was one more twist.

Since the Google access token had to go into the Authorization header to authenticate the request to cloud run, the original jwt from btp would be overwritten. And that JWT still had value - it carried user identity and roles needed for application-level checks.

So, using a policy in SAP API Hub, we copied the original JWT into a custom header( say,x-btp-user-token). This way , the cloud run service could still validate the logged-in user and enforce role-based access - without losing the secure handshake with google.

A little orchestration, a little header juggling - and just like that, I had a secure federated, and role-aware integration .

Final Thoughts

And that's a wrap! From tokens to trust, we've walked through the secure path of integrating SAP BTP with Google Cloud using workload identity federation.

Tried a different approach? Faced a twist I didn't covered? Drop it in the comments - lets learn from each other and keep the collaboration going.

Cheers!!!

entry.title: SAP Community Voice: Popular Posts, Blog It Forward, Site Updates, and More
entry.content:
We were really happy to see the positive response to the relaunch of our online SAP Community Voice newsletter. Based on this reaction, we‚Äôre aiming to deliver two newsletters per month, following the same cadence as the retired email version. That means every few weeks (likely on the 15th and final day of every month), we‚Äôll publish a post in What‚Äôs New to highlight popular member-contributed content, a summary of important community news, a look at upcoming events, and more.

Enjoy this latest edition, and we‚Äôll be back before the end of August with another newsletter!

 

Featured Content

 

SAP Datasphere Replication Flow Logs: Monitoring and Insights

We love content that draws engagement, and this contribution from @vikasparmar88 does just that! He writes about how to track replication-flow execution by accessing key metadata tables and diagnostic views within SAP Datasphere, and members are expressing their gratitude (and following up) in the comments.

Read the blog post

entry.title: Bringing Back Badges to Reward Q&A Experts!
entry.content:
If you‚Äôve been a long-time member of SAP Community, you‚Äôve probably accumulated several badges over the years. Even newer members may have earned the basic one-time badges available on our current platform ‚Äì such as the badge for taking our tutorial and the various badges awarded for a first-time action (e.g., replying, leaving a kudo). Members haven‚Äôt, however, been able to receive ongoing recognition for repeated activity.

That will change starting tomorrow (Tuesday, August 19).

With our previous gamification system, we rewarded badges for posting quality content, providing helpful answers, and more ‚Äì giving members the opportunity to earn multiple awards for frequent participation. (As an example, take a look at my list of badges ‚Äì which pales compared to the accomplishments of veterans who have been around since the earliest days of our online community!) As of August 19, we‚Äôre bringing this recognition back, starting with progression badges based on the number of answers accepted as solutions.

If you like answering questions (and you‚Äôre gifted at helping other members find solutions to their problems), then you‚Äôve probably already received the first badge in this new series ‚Äì by giving an answer that was accepted as a solution. Now you can earn an additional four badges, depending on the number of solutions you provided in Q&A.

We‚Äôll be rewarding people retroactively, so depending on your Q&A activity and length of community membership (going back to previous community platforms), you may get one or more badges tomorrow.

Not sure of your numbers? You can find them in your community content area. After logging in, click on the person icon in the upper right of any community page, then select ‚ÄúMy content.‚Äù

You‚Äôll see your total number of answers in the Private Stats section at the bottom of your ‚ÄúMy content‚Äù area.

But remember: an answer is not a solution. An answer becomes a solution when someone accepts it as the correct answer to a question. You‚Äôll find your total number of solutions in the gray box at the top of your ‚ÄúMy content‚Äù page.

So in this example, this member should expect to get all four of the new solutions badges. With 93 solutions, he has achieved the necessary criteria for the second badge (2 solutions), third badge (5 solutions), fourth badge (25 solutions), and the fifth and final badge in this progression series (50 solutions). (I sure hope he‚Äôs reading this, so he won‚Äôt wonder what‚Äôs going on when he sees four badge notifications tomorrow.)

If you are expecting badges, and you're not seeing them yet, try logging out and in again. That should update the badge list in your ‚ÄúMy content‚Äù page.

With this new badge set, SAP Community is once again acknowledging the awesome members who regularly contribute quality content. And we‚Äôre not stopping here! In the near future, we plan to introduce other progression sets. We don‚Äôt want to give away too much information just yet ‚Äì we thought it would be fun to keep things a surprise ‚Äì but we do encourage you to get more active, as you may find yourself receiving bigger badge payoffs very soon.

Make sure to monitor the What‚Äôs New section for announcements about the new progression badge sets as they become available. In the meantime, if you frequently participate in the community, keep up the good work. Or if you‚Äôre more of a lurker, consider jumping in and building up the numbers necessary for badges. Depending on what you do (and what you‚Äôve done), you may find yourself the recipient of several shiny new badges as we extend the ways in which we show appreciation for those who make our community a better place!

OK, one hint: We aren‚Äôt just going to reward the members active in Q&A, so if answering questions isn‚Äôt your thing, you can still gain badges for other activities. Experiment with meaningful contributions, show your support for other members, and see what happens!

entry.title: Story Time - The letters "D" and "K"
entry.content:
Hey, everybody. I'm here today in the Newtown Square Library, and I want to share something with you in story time mode. Today's story is going to focus on two letters, the letters D and K. Now, those letters might make you think of a band or maybe a fashion icon, but for me, they connect to something different.

Back in June, I was lucky enough to get to go to our SAP developer meeting in Dresden, Germany, and then I also went to the one in Mannheim. While I was in Dresden, I met someone who rocks blue hair like me. Her name is Doreen Kaestner. here is a photo of me and Doreen.

And she gave me something. This bracelet. I'm not a Swifty, but I have a friendship bracelet now from Doreen from Dresden, and it says SAP Dresden on it. And I've worn it ever since. The only time I take it off is when I touch up my beard, which I need to do this weekend. But I don't want to get blue hair dye all over the bracelet. So that's the only time I take it off. Otherwise, it stays on. And it's not just about Dresden and Doreen. It's a reminder of the entire SAP community, the family I'm proud to be a part of.

 

So fast forward a few weeks. I'm down in the LATAM Roadshow in South America. I do a few events in Brazil and Lima, Peru. And then I go home because it's time for vacation. And I found myself with my family in Stockholm, Sweden. Out of nowhere, in old city near the water, someone shouts, Hey, I know you! You're from SAP. And I was like, yeah. I shook his hand and I said, hey, what's your name? He said, I'm Dorian Kaucher, DK, another DK, just like Doreen. Dorian works in a small office in southern Germany called Markdorf and focuses on sustainability initiatives. And when I asked if I could take a picture with him, he said, well, I need one, too, because I want to show all my colleagues back in the office that I met you.

 Honestly it's it's crazy because you all make me so much better by being a part of this SAP community by showing up and by connecting but it's so flattering right the energy i get from being able to be recognized is awesome and i appreciate that but i wish i could remember all your names and all your initials when i meet you but these moments they matter they matter to me so know that i do keep them inside they really do matter so from Dresden to Stockholm June to August, all the way through the year, all the way through Latin America, all the time. I'm thinking about you and you give me so much energy. And I love being a part of this SAP community because of that and because of you. So I invite you, though, that if you need something, I can help you connect to other people. So for Dorian, if you want to connect with him and talk about sustainability initiatives and all the great work him and his team are doing down in Markdorf, let me know. And if you need help from Doreen with some development, she's over in Dresden and if she can't help you with her SAP skills, maybe somebody else on the team can, she'll help connect you. I love being a connector, and other people can then connect others from that. So it's a great thing being a part of this SAP community, online and in person.

And speaking of online, Devtoberfest starts the last week of September. So I hope you're registered, and we'll see you online for that for four weeks. And then on November 4th, we're going to be online and in person for SAP TechEd. We're going to be in Berlin November 4th through 6th as well as Louisville, KY the same dates with an on tour stop, and then some of us go the next week to Sydney, Australia and after that a couple weeks later we're in Bengaluru, India.

So I promise with all of this happening I'll have more stories for you very soon. Thank you for reading, bye.

entry.title: Dive into the future of SAP Universal ID and understand the changes underway
entry.content:
As valued members of our Community, we‚Äôd like to share upcoming changes to SAP Universal ID (UID). It is important that you have all the details to make the transition as simple as possible.

SAP is updating its SAP Universal ID framework to simplify user experiences and improve security. The key change is that the UID will no longer serve as an identity provider, meaning it will no longer represent a digital gatekeeper that checks if the person logging in is really who they say they are. Moving forward, users will have to use their e-mail address or user ID (S-/P-user) to log in. Please note that the SAP Universal ID will still be used as a wallet to collect and store user identities, community reputation and learning certificates.

The information below provides you with a view into the current state of SAP Universal ID, the upcoming changes, benefits of this evolution, and the impact on you.  

If you have any issues during the migration and this article doesn‚Äôt address them, our SAP support can help.

What is SAP Universal ID?

SAP Universal ID (UID) was created to serve as a unified personal account or wallet across all SAP systems, managing and linking various user identities such as S-/P-users. This consolidation ensured that learning certificates, awards, and community reputation are retained lifelong, regardless of organizational changes.

What¬¥s changing and what does this mean to you?

As mentioned above, SAP Universal ID will no longer serve as an identity provider. Instead, users will be authenticated through the SAP standard authentication mechanism (SAP IAS).

This change in the authentication approach requires a user password migration for all users of SAP Universal ID. For most users, those with only one user identity (S-/P-users) linked in SAP Universal ID, the password migration will happen automatically. No action is required from those users. They will continue to log in using their email address and the password they are accustomed to.

Users with more than one user identity (S-/P-users) linked in SAP Universal ID will be guided through a step-by-step process to set new password or confirm existing passwords. This will occur during the migration period, that takes place from August 25th till September 29th, 2025.

The SAP Universal ID account will remain active, allowing users to keep linking and managing their user identities in the SAP UID Account Manager. Another benefit of the UID Password Migration initiative for end users is that they lay the foundation for the future introduction of 'Remember me' functionality. Although the enablement timeline cannot be confirmed at this stage, technical preparations are underway, and we will communicate once the feature becomes available.

From September 29th, users will login with their e-mail address or user identity with the associated password. Single sign-on with SAP Universal ID will not be possible anymore. Users who haven‚Äôt gone through the password migration procedure during the mentioned period, will need to log in with any of their S-/P-user ID (or the email address associated to it) and a respective password, that was initially set during user creation. In case the password is forgotten, the ‚Äúforgot password‚Äù link can be used for reset. Passwords for the remaining users can be subsequently reset once logged in to the SAP Account Manager.

Why Is SAP Making This Change? 

This change is part of SAP‚Äôs broader identity renovation strategy. As SAP continues to evolve its identity and management solutions, the transition to identity renovation represents a new chapter in digital identity consolidation and management. While SAP Universal ID remains a pivotal part of this strategy, the shift towards SAP IAS sessions highlights the dynamic nature of enterprise technology. For customers and partners understanding and adapting to these changes will ensure optimized digital interactions within the SAP ecosystem. 

You can learn more about it in the Bring Your Own Identity: SAP's Strategic Transformation of Identity and Authentication Management blog post.

Detailed User Guide

This guide shows the single steps, you will be asked to go through to set or confirm your passwords during the UID password migration. Please note, that these steps will be required only from users with more than one user identity (S/P-user) linked in their SAP Universal ID. If you belong to the majority users, that have only one user identity (just one either S- or P-user) linked to their UID, the migration will happen automatically in the background and no action will be needed from you.

1. Once you log in, we will ask you to set new passwords to the user identities, that are linked in your SAP Universal ID. You have also the option to choose ‚Äúremind me later‚Äù. In that case, we will ask you again the next time you log in. Please keep in mind, that you should fulfill these steps until September 29th.

2. In the next screen, you will see all your linked user identities. You can either keep and confirm current password, choose to use the UID password or set a completely new password. You need to choose one of the options for each linked user identity. Once done, click on ‚Äúconfirm‚Äù.

3. To confirm your choices, we will ask you for your current SAP Universal ID password:

4. You will see a summary of your choices, once you confirmed with your UID password:

After setting successfully your passwords, you will be able to log in with your e-mail address or S-/P-user ID with the associated password.

Further Resources

Read our News article to know more about SAP‚Äôs Strategic Transformation of Identity and Authentication Management.  If you have any issues during the migration and this article didn‚Äôt address them, our SAP support can help.

Many Industries consider the manufacturing location as a plant in SAP. Under the plant, many storage locations would be available in SAP and some of them would be either IM managed (or Lean Warehouse managed), or Stock Room Managed (StRM) or EWM managed.
